Bobby Fischer.Action: Crushes a fly with a coffee cup in a cold, violent manner.
Remains motionless and focused on chess, showing no reaction to police arrival and knocking, but claws the arm of the chair like an animal in a trap.
Sits calmly and intently studies a chess position early in the morning, exhibiting intense focus and control over distractions.
Crushes a fly with a coffee cup decisively and quickly, demonstrating sharp reflexes and assertiveness.
Maintains a business-like demeanor despite tense and potentially threatening external events, showing mental resilience and self-control.
Claws at the armchair like an animal in a trap when police arrive, revealing underlying anxiety or stress in high-pressure situations.
Shrinks away when Uncle Paul tries to hug him
Responds politely but shortly to Uncle Paul’s questions
Pays attention and tries to warn his mother about the suspicious car
Shrinks away from Uncle Paul's hug, wary of unfamiliar or uncomfortable social interaction.
Accepts money from Uncle Paul cautiously, eyes widen, aware of implications.
Remembers and reports detailed description of suspicious car to his mother despite being told not to bother her.
Joan takes Bobby's hand and leads him away; Bobby accepts without resistance.
Bobby isolates himself, blocking out noise to be alone with his chessboard and notebook.
Recalls advice about not revealing information under pressure and rehearses a prepared response confidently.
Prepares by blocking out external noise skillfully and quickly to focus intensely on the chessboard despite distractions.
Cries when he loses, showing emotional sensitivity.
Glares briefly at Joan when she mentions he cries, then returns to focus.
Refuses to join any chess club and is self-taught, indicating possible social isolation or unwillingness to engage socially.
Joan takes his hand and leads him out, suggesting he allows some trust and connection with close companions.
Plays chess in his head constantly, showing deep focus and dedication.
Makes a sudden move that startles his opponent and traps him in a winning position.
Self-taught and does not belong to any club, yet competes at a high level.
Shows a strong dislike for draws, seeking decisive victories.
Mumbles hello when introduced to Carmine Nigro, somewhat reserved and shy.
Walks into the Brooklyn Chess Club reverently, as if entering a holy place.
Pushes his chair back and walks away, fighting back tears after losing a game.
Returns immediately after loss to reset the board and demand to play again.
Shakes hands with opponents, receives a medal, and responds modestly to questions about his future.
Ignores a kid yelling an antisemitic slur and is oblivious to the taunt.
Throws trophy haphazardly on sofa, covers window with aluminum foil, and dismisses his mother's presence during practice.
Beats American Master Donald Byrne in the 'Game of the Century' and becomes the youngest ever U.S. Chess Champion with longest string of victories.
Responds to reporter's question with modest but confident statement about his growing strength.
Struts confidently in a sharp suit while carrying trophy, appearing self-assured.
Oblivious to mocking kids on the street, instead focused on playing chess in his head.
Uses aluminum foil to cover a window believing it will protect against radiation from Sputnik satellites, despite lacking sound scientific basis.
Throws trophy haphazardly on a sofa, indicating possible disregard for accomplishments or disorganization.
Tells mother not to come in because he can't concentrate with her presence, showing self-awareness about his focus but potential social bluntness.
Expresses a hostile wish that his mother might get blown up by a 'Commie nuke' while marching for peace.
Dismisses his mother's peace activism with sarcastic remarks about her chaining herself to the White House.
Leaves abruptly without explanation when asked where he is going, showing disregard for others' concern.
Yells angrily at visitor, demands silence, flings shoes out the street.
Refuses to appreciate others' efforts to help him, dismissive toward Joan and others.
Declares he is training day and night to be the youngest world champion and demands silence to focus.
Flings shoes into the street and storms out in anger.
Is found asleep at the chess club with his suit wrinkled and filthy.
Smiles warmly with a grin described as 'like the sun breaking through the clouds.'
Responds to reporter's question about success by bluntly saying 'I'm better than everybody else' without guile.
States confidently, 'I'm better than everybody else.'
Becomes the youngest ever Grandmaster in history.
Plays twenty opponents at once and handles the challenge skillfully.
Acknowledges the difficulty of advancing in rankings but expresses readiness when opportunity comes.
Explains chess opponents' strategies knowledgeably and enthusiastically to Carmine.
Accuses Russian players of colluding and forcibly draws attention to unfair play with raised voice in the tournament hall.
Ignores Carmine's warning about disqualification to continue confrontation.
Yanks Carmine’s arm away forcefully when interrupted.
Pushes an official who falls but then tries to help him to his feet and apologizes for pushing him.
Makes a public statement apologizing for his outburst and showing concern for the official.
Accuses Russians loudly of cheating and conspiracies.
Declares chess moves confidently, correctly identifying a winning sequence (Knight to Kings Pawn Six, Bishop to Bk4, King to e-5, Queen to Qp2. King to Nb6, Queen to Bd3. Mate).
Storms out of the tournament room in frustration and publicly accuses opponents of cheating.
Physically pushes an official and then immediately apologizes and shows concern.
Attempts to make a public statement accusing the Russians of fixing the tournament, showing a lack of diplomatic skill and poor handling of the situation.
Expresses anger and quits chess in a public, confrontational manner, insults others, knocks over chair and walks away
Ignores Carmine's attempt to reason with him, dismisses others' feelings or perspectives
Wakes up to visit from Joan and her daughter, acknowledges Joan calmly
Expresses frustration about corruption and quits championship out of protest.
Confidently declares he is the best in the world and recognizes system is rigged against him.
Dismisses Carmine's attempt to reason and walks away refusing to face competition.
Explains chess pieces gently and encouragingly to Lizzie, inviting her to try playing.
Allows Joan to comb his hair and closes his eyes to the tenderness, a rare display of vulnerability.
Smiles and makes a lighthearted joke to Maria to ease the tension at their date.
Shows dismissiveness or impatience when talking to Joan about being too busy and the political issues in chess.
Jokes somewhat insensitively about virginity, which causes discomfort to Maria.
Maria is unnerved but drawn to his eyes; he makes playful political jokes that make her laugh
Rearranges sugar cubes instead of engaging in eating; seems puzzled by Maria's laughter
Smiles at Maria, calls her 'Beautiful' and stares at her face making her blush
Touches Maria gently on nose, chin, eyes, cheeks, and ears tenderly as he explains chess moves using her face as a chessboard
He gently touches Maria’s face while naming chess pieces, showing a tender and careful manner.
Comments 'Beautiful like a Picasso' to Maria, indicating poetic appreciation and possible affection.
Says 'You believe in love.' and then leaves with a sigh, showing emotional complexity but also causing Maria to feel forlorn.
Walks hunched and fast, somewhat furtive, ducking into the bookstore like someone embarrassed or secretive.
Requests the Bookstore Owner speak to him in American despite the Russian owner speaking softly and kindly, indicating impatience or rudeness.
Engages in Russian language conversation with the Bookstore Owner, showing willingness to communicate culturally.
Mentally visualizes and manipulates chess pieces on a person's face skillfully, showing strong imaginative and strategic capacity.
Displays trouble or hesitation when staring at Maria's face after imagining moves, indicating some internal conflict or doubt.
Walks into a Russian bookstore to acquire specialized chess materials, suggesting proactive knowledge seeking and resourcefulness.
Demands to be spoken to in American English before switching to Russian, showing confidence and control over the situation.
Memorizes an opponent’s chess moves at lightning speed from a magazine, demonstrating exceptional skill and mental sharpness.
Offers to play a game with Marshall, despite initial suspicion.
Rocks back and forth when asked about anger, showing vulnerability.
Responds curtly and ambiguously to lawyer Marshall, showing emotional distance.
Jokes lightly with Marshall, showing some playfulness and sociability.
Memorizes each move at lightning speed in a blitz tournament.
Initiates a chess game against someone approaching him in the park, showing confidence in his skill.
Writes a provocative article accusing Russians of fixing chess, indicating strategic thinking and boldness.
Rocks back and forth a little when questioned about anger and politics, revealing some internal conflict or instability.
Responds to serious questions with a coy joke, indicating wit but possibly evading or deflecting.
Acknowledges his isolation with 'All I have is this....'
Dismisses opponents and rivals with 'Screw him. Screw Boris Spassky.'
Laughs at Marshall's persistence and opportunity pitch, showing guardedness.
Declares he has 'moves in my brain like bullets' and claims deep knowledge of Spassky's games and thinking.
Expresses uncertainty about whether he can still play at a high level.
Dismisses his opponent Spassky with emotional language and confident gesture (tapping his temple).
Acknowledges personal isolation and sacrifice ('All I have is this...') implying focus but also possible emotional cost.
Shows a wicked smile when talking about winning.
Is described as a bad loser who complains about the environment, e.g., room too loud, lamp too bright.
Writes a letter of explanation and apology to the Federation, indicating some attempt at accountability.
Holds a long-standing grudge and studies opponents obsessively, reflecting a focused but possibly intolerant nature.
Has studied how the Russians play every day, eighteen hours a day for four years.
Asks for Lombardy to be his second, demonstrating strategic thinking and respect for expertise.
Writes a letter of explanation and apology to the Federation with strong language, indicating a lack of political tact.
Was a bad loser at age twelve, complaining about room conditions.
Wicked smile spreading across his face when talking about winning, showing confidence.
Criticizes Father Lombardy's chess moves bluntly but then jokes about criticizing a priest and acknowledges a 'good move' with a nod.
Eagerly demonstrates how Father Lombardy could have won by showing moves and explaining strategy in detail.
Slaps chess pieces down arrogantly and calls the Russians 'boa constrictors', showing aggressive, intense style and arrogance.
Ignores Lombardy’s comment about diplomacy and immediately demands five hundred dollars per game.
I want to buy my sister something for her new baby.
Stops taking medication because it impaired his play, mentioning it casually.
Describes the chess moves with dramatic narrative engaging Lombardy’s interest.
Jokes mildly calling Lombardy ‘Father? Take the crazy kid to California.’
Shakes his head and rejects staying at a seedy motel, expressing discomfort with the environment.
Carefully assesses the motel conditions and refuses to stay in an unsuitable place, demonstrating discernment and control over his surroundings.
Shakes his head at the seedy motel, signaling dissatisfaction but without immediate plan or alternative shown yet.
Acknowledges the hooker's presence and apologizes for yelling, asks her name, and agrees to walk with her.
Expresses frustration about the poor accommodations and lack of quiet but engages politely with others around him.
Dismisses concerns about money and privately funded support, demanding better conditions for himself.
Walks with purpose, mumbling and lost in a game in his head, somewhat detached from Donna following him.
Responds bluntly to Donna's questions and comments, e.g., 'Huh? Collect shells if you want.'
Sits down quietly on the sand, staring out to sea, allowing Donna to sit beside him without protest.
Engages in casual sex-for-money negotiation with Donna, showing some humor and openness.
Shows a bit of self-deprecating honesty about his virginity and social awkwardness.
Plays blind chess with Lombardy, grinning and engaging in friendly banter.
Tears up the intelligence folder mockingly and boasts about outsmarting the Russians.
Writes a letter to his mother asking Marshall to give it to her and expresses concern about her watching him play, revealing his fragile, sensitive side.
Hides away in the men's room to find quiet before his match, showing a need for solitude rather than engaging with others.
Arrives late, saunters in casually, creating psychological pressure on his opponent by counting down aloud and staring him down with a devilish smile
Acknowledges applause with a raised hand
Arrives late to the game, causing opponent to forfeit.
Uses psychological tactics by casually entering and counting down loudly to unnerve opponent.
Slaps his first move and clock confidently, maintaining intense eye contact.
Demands multiple conditions (luxury transportation, a cut of ticket sales, physical distance from audience) before agreeing to play
Insists on specific conditions before playing again, including arriving in a big black car like the Russians and demanding a share of gate receipts based on his popularity.
Demands respect and monetary compensation reflecting his star status, showing awareness of the business and psychological aspects surrounding chess.
Uses negotiations to assert control over his circumstances before tournaments, demonstrating confidence and strategic thinking beyond the chessboard.
Grins and makes a self-deprecating joke to Lombardy, disarming him and causing a smile.
Acts suspiciously and aggressively, demanding bug checks and breaking phones.
Walks off alone, dismissing offered transportation, showing aloofness.
Checks for phone bugs, refuses limo to walk, intensely prepares with Lombardy, displays disarming confidence and strategic thinking in discussion about opponents' moves.
Breaks multiple phones looking for bugs, showing possible paranoia and destructiveness.
Hesitates before shaking Boris Spassky's hand, shows flicker of doubt but ultimately proceeds.
Responds harshly to Lombardy's advice, then immediately apologizes showing awareness and ability to self-correct.
Bursts out in fury after losing, shows emotional unraveling and inability to maintain composure.
Walks away from media and social duties after loss, avoiding engagement and responsibility.
Draws chessboard in the sand post loss, reflecting deeply on his failure.
Is described as intensely focused on chess, to the point that without it he 'doesn't exist.'
Receptive to and accepting government support including limos and honorariums for victories.
Remains absent from the scene, with others discussing his severe mental problems and challenges.
Described as the second best chess player Lombardy has ever seen; undefeated against top masters by age 21 and has exceptional chess skills like playing multiple opponents blindfolded.
Exhibits severe mental problems that suggest instability and difficulty managing his own mind, raising concerns about his longevity and consistent performance.
Resists traditional pathways to the title given the grueling requirements of travel and competition, indicating possible avoidance of necessary professional endurance.
Yells at Boris about the KGB men being jailers, not bodyguards, showing concern for Boris's mental state
Leaps into the ocean fully clothed to play and demonstrate freedom, cheerfully encouraging Boris
Takes a sardonic bow after provoking the KGB minders, showing playful defiance
Leaps to his feet and yells at Boris about the KGB men, showing awareness of the psychological manipulation involved.
Steps into the ocean fully clothed and plays in the waves, exhibiting confidence and psychological resilience after a loss.
Takes a sardonic bow after provoking the KGB minders, signaling a confident and skillful psychological tactic.
Smiles with a big grin while boasting 'The Russians are afraid of me, man.'
Freezes and angrily tells reporters, 'I have nothing to say to you!!'
Relentlessly pushes himself to do more sets in workout despite being wasted.
Hands the pen to Lombardy after finishing a winning chess game.
Enjoys the attention of female fans, engages openly with Lombardy, and shows curiosity about religious teachings.
Deflects or avoids personal questions about his mother and father, abruptly ends an interview, and walks away when pushed.
Enjoys the fruits of stardom and confidently interacts with Lombardy.
Listens attentively to the cult preacher's authoritative message, showing openness to new information.
Questions government knowledge about radiation and ICBMs, indicating curiosity and critical thinking.
Avoids discussing personal matters with the interviewer and abruptly leaves the conversation.
Grins and interacts playfully with a young fan in the hallway, signing an autograph and joking to lightheartedly discourage competition.
Insists firmly and angrily on specific playing conditions (lighting, table placement), refusing to compromise and threatening not to play.
Insists on specific conditions for the match (lighting, clocks, table space), showing detailed knowledge and control over the tournament environment.
Uses his reputation and achievements to negotiate better pay, linking his value to his championships and media impact.
Demands things in an aggressive, uncompromising manner ('Then I won't play'), risking alienating organizers.
Engages warmly and confidently with a fan, using humor and charisma.
Cuts off conversation abruptly and walks away when uninterested, potentially missing opportunities for constructive dialogue.
Writes letters with delusional content, including paranoid and hateful statements about Jews.
Marshall states it has been a while since Joan saw him but he is in great shape; Joan produces letters showing signs of delusional psychosis and paranoid beliefs.
Marshall acknowledges the beauty of the games Fischer is playing despite his paranoid statements.
Grandmasters are watching Bobby play with tears in their eyes.
Beats Russian grandmaster Tigran Petrosian in the semi-final of the World Chess Championships.
Calmly acknowledges his win and admits improvising answers during media interaction.
Confidently declares his dominance over Petrosian and anticipates overpowering Spassky.
Engages playfully with his team, grins, enjoys moment despite anxiety about being bugged.
Responds to questions with suspicion and dismissiveness about 'people' worried about him.
Expresses paranoid beliefs about being bugged and monitored, hearing buzzing sounds and even through his teeth fillings.
Grins and laughs confidently when reporters mention opponents getting sick, showing confidence and assertiveness.
Rejects some media appearances to avoid distraction, showing selective control and focus on priorities.
Repeats and demands clarity about 'people' being worried to Marshall, displaying fixation and possible paranoia that limits effective communication.
Confronts Marshall angrily for talking behind his back and about him with his sister without permission.
Refuses to tolerate disloyalty or lack of transparency in his relationships.
Stops the car abruptly and demands control of situation, refusing to allow others to operate behind his back.
Engages in covert chess moves with Lombardy while walking, regaining focus and demonstrating skill.
Angrily confronts Marshall about talking to his sister and acting without consent.
Overreacts emotionally and refuses communication with supporter (Marshall), displaying possible paranoia and mistrust.
Requests removal of the TV from his room believing Russians are watching him through the screen.
Appears highly distrustful and paranoid toward others, including his own safety, causing alienation.
Appears shy and cocky during the interview, laughs easily, and shows lack of guile.
Accuses opponents (Soviets) openly of cheating, encouraging laughter at their expense.
When asked about weakness, responds honestly and with easy laughter, showing some sincerity.
Expresses satisfaction in 'breaking the opponent’s ego,' delighting in their emotional defeat.
Becomes US Chess Champion at fourteen and Grandmaster at fifteen.
Engages in a confident and sharp interview, openly accusing Soviets of cheating.
Declares having no weaknesses when asked about his vulnerabilities.
Appears both shy and cocky, displaying a mix of humility and confidence in public.
Yells over music demanding a higher concert ticket percentage, refuses to honor signed agreement.
Declares he plays not just for himself but for the game of Chess, acknowledges Spassky as reigning champion, attempts to justify his demands.
Turns off music and replaces it with a tape from The Worldwide Church of God, indicating insistence on his own preferences.
Responds tersely to Lombardy's suggestion not to go if he doesn't want to, saying 'I thought you wanted me to win.'
Dismisses psychological help with hostility and antisemitic remark; rejects Lombardy's attempt to help
Calls Lombardy 'loser' and verbally attacks him harshly
Feels contrite immediately after harsh tirade and tries to engage Lombardy with new chess idea
Shoves aside Marshall (security) and runs back down the up escalator to avoid journalists.
Leaps into a taxi and orders driver to drive quickly, then hides down in the cab with eyes darting.
Sits alone at a chessboard early in the morning; chessboards covered with dust; unavailable for match despite expectations and diplomatic pressure.
Fails to arrive on time for the highly publicized World Chess Championship match, causing embarrassment and diplomatic tension.
Sits alone at a chessboard in his apartment, implying intense focus and dedication to the game despite external pressures.
Calls Joan urgently for comfort and expresses feeling overwhelmed and scared.
Paranoia about being listened to and pursued, causing him to whimper and react fearfully when others arrive.
Dialing the phone to reach out to Joanie, attempting to communicate and seek support.
Expresses paranoia about people listening and invading his privacy, feeling overwhelmed and unable to think about chess.
Confronts the intruders with clenched fists despite being overwhelmed, showing readiness to defend himself.
Objects to paying for a phone call, challenges the cost, complains about ticket prices and payment.
Takes the phone and listens to Kissinger, visibly moved and almost sobs, then agrees to do his duty.
Expresses being moved by the house, recalling it as the first house he lived in.
Shows vulnerability and desperation when asking Lombardy for help looking for listening devices, calling him 'Father' as a sign of closeness and trust.
Walks past Spassky without shaking his hand at first, greeting the adjudicator and crowd instead; then notices Spassky, smiles, and greets him warmly with a handshake and friendly words.
Strides confidently onto the stage despite mixed crowd reactions, greets the adjudicator formally, waves to the crowd, then engages Spassky with a casual, informal greeting.
Initially ignores the reigning champion Spassky's extended hand, potentially risking a negative impression.
Imitates a particular cough viciously at the audience, paces nervously and complains loudly about buzzing noises and coughing, lashes out at the crowd asking them to be quiet.
Fails to maintain concentration due to distractions and complains openly about coughing, buzzing, and cameras during the match.
Attempts to take control of the environment by requesting to remove cameras and silence the crowd to improve conditions.
Asks audience to move back to reduce distractions
Appears distracted and anxious, focusing inward rather than engaging others
Points out problems with the environment (lights too dark, audience too close), indicating heightened situational awareness and attempts to control conditions to optimize his play.
Swings arms around to shake off distraction and returns to his seat, trying to recover composure and focus.
Gets distracted by sounds and movements in the audience, shows signs of anxiety and an anxiety attack, behavior indicating diminished ability to concentrate and control the game.
Invites Spassky to exchange a piece (bishop), indicating a strategic move during the game.
Exhibits visible signs of anxiety (heart pounding, ragged breathing) in the middle of the match, which can undermine confident and skilled behavior.
Leaps to his feet and demands TV cameramen out, accusing them of whispering and distracting him.
Stalks away in a fury after losing the game.
Makes a huge mistake during a critical game that shocks the crowd and media.
Reacting impulsively by confronting and removing TV cameramen from the stage, causing crowd to boo.
Rides in silence with companions, speaks in a detached, introspective manner revealing personal struggle
Reflects on the chessboard as 'alive' and expresses a deep emotional connection to the game
Stops breathing hard and looks around, seemingly disoriented but then finds a solution to his problems.
Speaks oddly detached, as if talking to himself, expressing confusion about his approach and not understanding what happened.
Rants about global power conspiracies with wild eyes, expressing paranoid beliefs about secret manipulation and indicating distrust toward others.
Rejects Lombardy's advice to focus on preparation, showing intolerance toward opposing viewpoints.
Scribbles a note and urgently gives it to Marshall to deliver, indicating a level of trust and sincere communication with his assistant.
Madly scribbles a note after a disastrous move in Game One, showing intense focus and unconventional thinking.
Rants about conspiracies and global power, distracted from practical chess preparation.
Ignores advice to prepare for the next day, instead focusing on external theories.
Demonstrates knowledge of the chess opponent’s influence and anticipates future obstacles.
Plays and laughs with an Icelandic pony, runs and strokes its mane.
Makes unreasonable demands for playing conditions (ping pong room, different board), leading to a forfeit.
Makes extreme and unreasonable demands for playing conditions (quiet room, different chess board) that interfere with the match.

Shows signs of fear or psychological struggle affecting his ability to compete effectively (hesitation, avoiding consequences of losing or winning).
Fails to show for a scheduled match, leading to opponent's forfeit and disqualification risk.
Checks his watch while on his knees, indicating awareness of time constraints albeit indecisive action afterward.

Disappears from his room despite pressure and demands from others to come out
Makes unusual demands about the game location (a store room), leading to widespread ridicule
Hears Marshall calling excitedly and responds calmly; picks up bicycle and cycles away to the ping pong room without fuss.

Calmly picks up the bicycle and cycles away purposefully instead of rushing with panic.

Makes a bold, risky chess move that unnerves opponents and excites the crowd.
Exposes his Queen, baiting Spassky to take it, setting a trap which leads to a decisive counterattack.

Maintains total focus and an implacable demeanor during the game, displaying intense concentration and mental readiness.

Declines Lombardy's offer for anything, gives short, lifeless replies, avoids engagement
Allows Lombardy to quietly put a pen in his pocket without protest or rejection
Expresses deep existential loneliness ('Not even me') and emotional vulnerability
Maintains a serene and focused demeanor after winning; shows a still and empty mind, not gloating or arrogant

Appears confused and astonished when Boris Spassky stands and applauds him, reflecting humility and perhaps surprise at kindness
Panics and withdraws from overwhelming crowd attention, showing discomfort with fan interactions.
Looks for familiar, trusted faces (mom, Joan, Uncle Paul) in the crowd, indicating longing for connection and support.

Reacting with visible panic and anxiety when overwhelmed by the crowd and attention.
Avoids engaging with invasive photographers and public attention by hiding or withdrawing (leans back out of sight in limo).
His later behavior showing descent into paranoia and conspiracy theories.
Expresses hostility toward the U.S. after 9-11, saying 'Time for the fucking U.S. to get their heads kicked in.'

Sits smiling on a bench, speaks sincerely about chess being intertwined with his life, and expresses genuine ambition with a slow smile.
Does not respond to Marshall's plea, remains silent and withdrawn.
Timidly follows sister Joan away from the window and returns to a chaotic party environment where he is invisible and overshadowed.
Stares at the chessboard with intense focus, shutting out distractions, totally absorbed in the game.
Firmly demands the intruders leave his room to maintain his playing environment.
Despite the disruption, remains engaged enough to request one more game from Joan after the board is reset.
Nods or moves chess pieces without looking up, indicating deep concentration and immersion in the chess game during his doctor's visit.
Returns to the board immediately after losing and demands to play again, showing determination and refusal to accept defeat.
Defeats one opponent after another at a tournament, demonstrating consistent skill and success.
Studies chess intensively in various everyday moments, including while making a sandwich and walking, indicating strong dedication and intelligent preparation.
Makes a move while distracted by a chess game in progress.
Shows ability to memorize chess diagrams from the Shakmanty Bulletin instantly with photographic memory.
Immediately leaves after figuring out the date, acting decisively without hesitation.
Expresses intense frustration and emotional distress about his absent father, aggressively confronts Regina and Cyril.
Shows vulnerability by asking sincere questions about his real father and his existence.
References historical chess games accurately, demonstrating detailed knowledge about Capablanca vs. Lasker endgame positions.

Critiques Petrosian's play with precise, confident analysis.
Demonstrates deep understanding by reconstructing lost game scenarios and moves rapidly to show winning strategy.
Dismisses concerns about diplomacy and focuses solely on chess and winning money.
Stops taking medication when it impairs his playing and resumes playing strongly.
Makes multiple tactical moves quickly and explains complex chess strategies with vivid, confident storytelling.
Walking with purpose, mumbling and envisioning a game being played in his head.
Engaging in haggling over a proposition with Donna in a confident, playful manner.
Spacing out and needing an external prompt to return to conversation.
Plays blind chess with Lombardy, demonstrating strong visualization and memorization of the board and moves.
Confidently dismisses Soviet preparation folder and expresses belief in his own readiness and superiority.
Tears up the background mimeo on opponents, showing defiant confidence.
Shows up late but unruffled, having found a quiet place to write a letter; handles the situation with calmness and focus.
Dismisses concern about his opponent's strength with confidence, correcting ranking and appearing self-assured.
Almost forfeits by being absent at the start; risks disqualification due to tardiness.
Fiercely dedicated to chess, the thing that defines his existence.
Understands the political and psychological significance of his match beyond just the game.
Behaves erratically (implied by 'a little off') and requires external support like limousines and honorariums.
Arrives in Reykjavik as the first American to reach the final against the World Champion, demonstrating exceptional skill and achievement in chess.
Tries to avoid the press by covering his head with a paper bag despite the cameras and intense media scrutiny, showing an awareness of pressure though possibly indicating social discomfort.
Insists on raising his concert ticket sales percentage from 25 to 30 percent despite prior agreement, demonstrating confidence and a strong sense of his own value.
Refuses to back down when challenged, showing stubbornness but also strategic assertion of his importance to the event.

Claims responsibility for the entire event's significance, stating he is 'the light shining on this game' and the main reason others are involved, revealing a confident self-assessment that may be accurate but borders on arrogance.
His manic pacing and emotionally intense speech reflect possible instability or impulsiveness, which could undermine calm and measured competence.
Calls Lombardy a loser and implies he’s a winner, showing confidence and assertiveness even in personal conflict.
Rejects psychological help and support from others, demonstrating a strong belief in self-reliance and independence.
Becomes immediately contrite after insulting Lombardy and attempts to engage him about chess strategies.
Calculates the maximum potential revenue from ticket sales, showing awareness of financial stakes and self-worth.
Initially reluctant and startled by the political pressure and attention from high-ranking officials.
Ultimately accepts the pressure from Kissinger and agrees to 'do his duty,' showing resolve and commitment despite nervousness.
Searches his room thoroughly for listening devices, showing vigilance and paranoia.
Expresses a deep emotional vulnerability, appearing wired and sleepless.
Allows a pony to lick his hand, showing calmness and gentle interaction with an animal.
Responds with a non sequitur ('Ping pong') when urged by Marshall to get ready, showing detachment and lack of cooperation.
Remains silent and unresponsive to Marshall's entreaties to open the door despite many messages from people wanting him to respond.
Absence leading to Boris’s frustration and despair indicates potential social withdrawal and lack of engagement with others.
Arrives wearing a sharp suit, immediately sits confidently at the table, showing readiness and self-assuredness.
Responds sarcastically but sharply to Schmid about letting Spassky watch him play, displaying confidence and control of the situation.
Exhibits a slow, satisfied smile while reveling in the stillness, showing calm composure under pressure.
Makes an unexpected first move (D4), choosing an opening he has never played before, surprising opponents and allies.
Playing the Benoni opening as Black while two games behind, an opening described by others as 'suicide', indicating a high-risk move that unsettles his rival.
Refuses to accept a draw, insisting on winning by continuing the game.
Makes moves that immediately counter Spassky's, successfully pressuring him across the board.
Bullying Spassky in the game, leading to Spassky's resignation.
Stays up all night playing chess alone, showing dedication and intense focus.
Does not engage in conversation about the game, appears emotionally and mentally distant, shows signs of exhaustion and detachment.
Reflects thoughtfully on the nature of the game and his situation, showing insight ('at the beginning of a game there are many options; at the end only one').
Chooses to return to the main hall despite distractions, indicating a deliberate coping mechanism and confidence in handling distractions.
Sits intensely focused, enters a zone of complete concentration where only the chessboard and moves exist.
Makes a surprising and powerful move that leaves opponents and commentators speechless and confused.
Maintains a blank, unreadable expression during critical moments, showing emotional control and confidence.
Playing 20 chess boards simultaneously with graceful and passionate movements at the height of his power.
Revoking of US passport, living in exile, becoming homeless due to alienating behavior.
Expresses strong confidence in becoming and remaining world chess champion for 20 years.
